trans-unit.source: Data Factory - Create Predictive Pipelines using Data Factory and Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Data Factory - Create Predictive Pipelines using Data Factory and Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how to create create predictive pipelines using Azuer Data Factory and Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Describes how to create create predictive pipelines using Azuer Data Factory and Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory enables you to easily create pipelines that leverages a published <linkText>Azure Machine Learning[azure-machine-learning]</linkText><title></title> web service for predictive analytics.
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory enables you to easily create pipelines that leverages a published <linkText>Azure Machine Learning[azure-machine-learning]</linkText><title></title> web service for predictive analytics.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to use Azure Data Factory to orchestrate data movement and processing, and then perform batch scoring using Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to use Azure Data Factory to orchestrate data movement and processing, and then perform batch scoring using Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: To achieve this, you will need to do the following:
trans-unit.target: To achieve this, you will need to do the following:

trans-unit.source: Use the AzureMLBatchScoring activity.
trans-unit.target: Use the AzureMLBatchScoring activity.

trans-unit.source: Request URI for the Batch Execution API.
trans-unit.target: Request URI for the Batch Execution API.

trans-unit.source: You can find the Request URI by clicking on the BATCH EXECUTION link in the web services page (shown below).
trans-unit.target: You can find the Request URI by clicking on the BATCH EXECUTION link in the web services page (shown below).

trans-unit.source: API key for the published Azure Machine Learning web service.
trans-unit.target: API key for the published Azure Machine Learning web service.

trans-unit.source: You can find this information by clicking on the web service that you have published.
trans-unit.target: You can find this information by clicking on the web service that you have published.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Machine Learning Dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Machine Learning Dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A predictive pipeline has these parts:
trans-unit.target: A predictive pipeline has these parts:

trans-unit.source: Input and output tables
trans-unit.target: Input and output tables

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage/Azure SQL and Azure ML linked services
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage/Azure SQL and Azure ML linked services

trans-unit.source: A pipeline with Azure ML Batch Scoring Activity
trans-unit.target: A pipeline with Azure ML Batch Scoring Activity

trans-unit.source: You can use Web service parameters that are exposed by a published Azure Machine Learning Web service in Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines.
trans-unit.target: You can use Web service parameters that are exposed by a published Azure Machine Learning Web service in Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Web Service Parameters section in this article.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Web Service Parameters section in this article.

trans-unit.source: This example uses Azure Storage to hold both the input and output data.
trans-unit.target: This example uses Azure Storage to hold both the input and output data.

trans-unit.source: You can also use Azure SQL Database instead of using Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Azure SQL Database instead of using Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you go through the <linkText>Build your first pipeline with Data Factory[adf-build-1st-pipeline]</linkText><title></title> tutorial prior to going through this example and use the Data Factory Editor to create Data Factory artifacts (linked services, tables, pipeline) in this example.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you go through the <linkText>Build your first pipeline with Data Factory[adf-build-1st-pipeline]</linkText><title></title> tutorial prior to going through this example and use the Data Factory Editor to create Data Factory artifacts (linked services, tables, pipeline) in this example.

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service for your Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service for your Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: If the scoring input and output files will be in different storage accounts, you will need two linked services.
trans-unit.target: If the scoring input and output files will be in different storage accounts, you will need two linked services.

trans-unit.source: Here is a JSON example:
trans-unit.target: Here is a JSON example:

trans-unit.source: Create the input Azure Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Create the input Azure Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: Note that unlike some other Data Factory tables, these must both contain both folderPath and fileName values.
trans-unit.target: Note that unlike some other Data Factory tables, these must both contain both folderPath and fileName values.

trans-unit.source: You can use partitioning to cause each batch execution (each data slice) to process or produce unique input and output files.
trans-unit.target: You can use partitioning to cause each batch execution (each data slice) to process or produce unique input and output files.

trans-unit.source: You will likely need to include some upstream activity to transform the input into the CSV file format and place it in the storage account for each slice.
trans-unit.target: You will likely need to include some upstream activity to transform the input into the CSV file format and place it in the storage account for each slice.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you would not include the external and externalData settings shown in the example below, and your ScoringInputBlob would be the output table of a different Activity.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you would not include the external and externalData settings shown in the example below, and your ScoringInputBlob would be the output table of a different Activity.

trans-unit.source: Your batch scoring csv file must have the column header row.
trans-unit.target: Your batch scoring csv file must have the column header row.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the Copy Activity to create/move the csv into the blob storage, you should set the sink property blobWriterAddHeader to true.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the Copy Activity to create/move the csv into the blob storage, you should set the sink property blobWriterAddHeader to true.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: If the csv file does not have the header row, you may see the following error: **Error in Activity: Error reading string.
trans-unit.target: If the csv file does not have the header row, you may see the following error: **Error in Activity: Error reading string.

trans-unit.source: Unexpected token: StartObject.
trans-unit.target: Unexpected token: StartObject.

trans-unit.source: Path '', line 1, position 1**.
trans-unit.target: Path '', line 1, position 1**.

trans-unit.source: Create the output Azure Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Create the output Azure Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: This example uses partitioning to create a unique output path for each slice execution.
trans-unit.target: This example uses partitioning to create a unique output path for each slice execution.

trans-unit.source: Without this, the activity would overwrite the file.
trans-unit.target: Without this, the activity would overwrite the file.

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service of type: AzureMLLinkedService, providing the API key and model batch scoring URL.
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service of type: AzureMLLinkedService, providing the API key and model batch scoring URL.

trans-unit.source: Finally, author a pipeline containing an AzureMLBatchScoringActivity.
trans-unit.target: Finally, author a pipeline containing an AzureMLBatchScoringActivity.

trans-unit.source: It will get the location of the input file from your input tables, call the AzureML batch scoring API, and copy the batch scoring output to the blob given in your output table.
trans-unit.target: It will get the location of the input file from your input tables, call the AzureML batch scoring API, and copy the batch scoring output to the blob given in your output table.

trans-unit.source: Unlike some other Data Factory activities, AzureMLBatchScoringActivity can have only one input and one output table.
trans-unit.target: Unlike some other Data Factory activities, AzureMLBatchScoringActivity can have only one input and one output table.

trans-unit.source: You can use Web service parameters that are exposed by a published Azure Machine Learning Web service in Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines.
trans-unit.target: You can use Web service parameters that are exposed by a published Azure Machine Learning Web service in Azure Data Factory (ADF) pipelines.

trans-unit.source: You can create an experiment in Azure Machine Learning and publish it as a web service, and then use that web service in multiple ADF pipelines or activities, passing in different inputs via the Web Service Parameters.
trans-unit.target: You can create an experiment in Azure Machine Learning and publish it as a web service, and then use that web service in multiple ADF pipelines or activities, passing in different inputs via the Web Service Parameters.

trans-unit.source: Add a typeProperties section to the AzureMLBatchScoringActivty section in the pipeline JSON to specify values for Web service parameters in that section as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Add a typeProperties section to the AzureMLBatchScoringActivty section in the pipeline JSON to specify values for Web service parameters in that section as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: You can also use <linkText>Data Factory Functions</linkText><title></title> in passing values for the Web service parameters as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: You can also use <linkText>Data Factory Functions</linkText><title></title> in passing values for the Web service parameters as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: The Web service parameters are case-sensitive, so ensure that the names you specify in the activity JSON match the ones exposed by the Web service.
trans-unit.target: The Web service parameters are case-sensitive, so ensure that the names you specify in the activity JSON match the ones exposed by the Web service.

trans-unit.source: A common scenario for using Web service parameters is the use of Azure SQL Readers and Writers.
trans-unit.target: A common scenario for using Web service parameters is the use of Azure SQL Readers and Writers.

trans-unit.source: The reader module is used to load data into an experiment from data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio and the writer module is to save data from your experiments into data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: The reader module is used to load data into an experiment from data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio and the writer module is to save data from your experiments into data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: For details about Azure Blob/Azure SQL reader/writer, see <linkText>Reader</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Writer</linkText><title></title> topics on MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: For details about Azure Blob/Azure SQL reader/writer, see <linkText>Reader</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Writer</linkText><title></title> topics on MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: The example in the previous section used the Azure Blob reader and Azure Blob writer.
trans-unit.target: The example in the previous section used the Azure Blob reader and Azure Blob writer.

trans-unit.source: This section discusses using Azure SQL reader and Azure SQL writer.
trans-unit.target: This section discusses using Azure SQL reader and Azure SQL writer.

trans-unit.source: In Azure ML Studio, you can build an experiment and publish a Web service with an Azure SQL Reader for the input.
trans-unit.target: In Azure ML Studio, you can build an experiment and publish a Web service with an Azure SQL Reader for the input.

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL Reader has connection properties that can be exposed as Web service parameters, allowing values for the connection properties to be passed at runtime in the batch scoring request.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL Reader has connection properties that can be exposed as Web service parameters, allowing values for the connection properties to be passed at runtime in the batch scoring request.

trans-unit.source: At runtime, the details from the input Data Factory table will be used by the Data Factory service to fill in the Web service parameters.
trans-unit.target: At runtime, the details from the input Data Factory table will be used by the Data Factory service to fill in the Web service parameters.

trans-unit.source: Note that you must use default names (Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, Server user account password) for the Web service parameters for this integration with the Data Factory service to work.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must use default names (Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, Server user account password) for the Web service parameters for this integration with the Data Factory service to work.

trans-unit.source: If you have any additional Web service parameters, use the webServiceParameters section of the activity JSON.
trans-unit.target: If you have any additional Web service parameters, use the webServiceParameters section of the activity JSON.

trans-unit.source: If you specify values for Azure SQL Reader parameters in this section, the values will override the values picked up from the input Azure SQL linked service.
trans-unit.target: If you specify values for Azure SQL Reader parameters in this section, the values will override the values picked up from the input Azure SQL linked service.

trans-unit.source: We do not recommend you specify values for Azure SQL Reader directly in the webServiceParameters section.
trans-unit.target: We do not recommend you specify values for Azure SQL Reader directly in the webServiceParameters section.

trans-unit.source: Use the section to pass values for any additional parameters.
trans-unit.target: Use the section to pass values for any additional parameters.

trans-unit.source: To use an Azure SQL Reader via an Azure Data Factory pipeline, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To use an Azure SQL Reader via an Azure Data Factory pipeline, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure SQL linked service.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure SQL linked service.

trans-unit.source: Create a Data Factory table that uses AzureSqlTable.
trans-unit.target: Create a Data Factory table that uses AzureSqlTable.

trans-unit.source: Set that Data Factory table as the input for the AzureMLBatchScoringActivity in the pipeline JSON.
trans-unit.target: Set that Data Factory table as the input for the AzureMLBatchScoringActivity in the pipeline JSON.

trans-unit.source: As with Azure SQL Reader, an Azure SQL Writer can also have its properties exposed as Web service parameters.
trans-unit.target: As with Azure SQL Reader, an Azure SQL Writer can also have its properties exposed as Web service parameters.

trans-unit.source: An Azure SQL Writer uses settings from either the linked service associated with the input table or the output table.
trans-unit.target: An Azure SQL Writer uses settings from either the linked service associated with the input table or the output table.

trans-unit.source: The following table describes when the input linked service is used vs. output linked service.
trans-unit.target: The following table describes when the input linked service is used vs. output linked service.

trans-unit.source: Output/Input
trans-unit.target: Output/Input

trans-unit.source: Input is Azure SQL
trans-unit.target: Input is Azure SQL

trans-unit.source: Input is Azure Blob
trans-unit.target: Input is Azure Blob

trans-unit.source: Output is Azure SQL
trans-unit.target: Output is Azure SQL

trans-unit.source:
The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the INPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password". Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.

If the Azure SQL Reader and Azure SQL Writer in your Azure ML model share the same Web service parameters mentioned above, you are fine. If they do not share same Web service paramers, for example, if the Azure SQL Writer uses parameters names: Database server name1, Database name1, Server user account name1, Server user account password1 (with '1' at the end), you must pass values for these OUTPUT web service parameters in the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON.

You can pass values for any other Web service parameters using the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON.
trans-unit.target:
The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the INPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password". Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.

If the Azure SQL Reader and Azure SQL Writer in your Azure ML model share the same Web service parameters mentioned above, you are fine. If they do not share same Web service paramers, for example, if the Azure SQL Writer uses parameters names: Database server name1, Database name1, Server user account name1, Server user account password1 (with '1' at the end), you must pass values for these OUTPUT web service parameters in the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON.

You can pass values for any other Web service parameters using the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON.

trans-unit.source:
The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the OUTPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password". Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.

You can pass values for any other Web service parameters using the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON .

Input blob will be used as input location.
trans-unit.target:
The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the OUTPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password". Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.

You can pass values for any other Web service parameters using the webServiceParameters section of activity JSON .

Input blob will be used as input location.

trans-unit.source: Output is Azure Blob
trans-unit.target: Output is Azure Blob

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the INPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password".
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service uses the connection string information from the INPUT linked service to generate the web service parameters with names: "Database server name", "Database name", "Server user account name", "Server user account password".

trans-unit.source: Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must use these default names for Web service parameters in Azure ML Studio.

trans-unit.source:
You must pass values for any Web service parameters using the WebServiceParameters section of activity JSON.

Blobs will be used as input and output locations.
trans-unit.target:
You must pass values for any Web service parameters using the WebServiceParameters section of activity JSON.

Blobs will be used as input and output locations.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Writer may encounter key violations if it is overwriting an identity column.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Writer may encounter key violations if it is overwriting an identity column.

trans-unit.source: You should ensure that you structure your output table to avoid this situation.
trans-unit.target: You should ensure that you structure your output table to avoid this situation.

trans-unit.source: You can use staging tables with a Stored Procedure Activity to merge rows, or to truncate the data before scoring.
trans-unit.target: You can use staging tables with a Stored Procedure Activity to merge rows, or to truncate the data before scoring.

trans-unit.source: If you use this approach, set concurrency setting of the executionPolicy to 1.
trans-unit.target: If you use this approach, set concurrency setting of the executionPolicy to 1.

trans-unit.source: When using the Reader module in an Azure Machine Learning experiment, you can specify Azure Blob as an input.
trans-unit.target: When using the Reader module in an Azure Machine Learning experiment, you can specify Azure Blob as an input.

trans-unit.source: The files in the Azure blob storage can be the output files (e.g. 000000_0) that are produced by a Pig and Hive script running on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: The files in the Azure blob storage can be the output files (e.g. 000000_0) that are produced by a Pig and Hive script running on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: The Reader module allows you to read files (with no extensions) by configuring the Path to container, directory or blob property of the reader module to point to the container/folder that contains the files as shown below.
trans-unit.target: The Reader module allows you to read files (with no extensions) by configuring the Path to container, directory or blob property of the reader module to point to the container/folder that contains the files as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Note, the asterisk (i.e. \*) specifies that all the files in the container/folder (i.e. data/aggregateddata/year=2014/month-6/\*) will be read as part of the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Note, the asterisk (i.e. \*) specifies that all the files in the container/folder (i.e. data/aggregateddata/year=2014/month-6/\*) will be read as part of the experiment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Blob properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Blob properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the above JSON example:
trans-unit.target: In the above JSON example:

trans-unit.source: The Azure ML model uses both Azure SQL Reader and Azure SQL Writer
trans-unit.target: The Azure ML model uses both Azure SQL Reader and Azure SQL Writer

trans-unit.source: When exposed via Web service, the default names are used for the parameters
trans-unit.target: When exposed via Web service, the default names are used for the parameters

trans-unit.source: For the reader: Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, and Server user account password.
trans-unit.target: For the reader: Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, and Server user account password.

trans-unit.source: For the writer: Database server name1, Database name1, Server user account name1, and Server user account password1.
trans-unit.target: For the writer: Database server name1, Database name1, Server user account name1, and Server user account password1.

trans-unit.source: Note that the reader and writer do not share parameters in this case.
trans-unit.target: Note that the reader and writer do not share parameters in this case.

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service automatically generates values for Web service parameters with the names Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, and Server user account password, which match the names of the input reader.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service automatically generates values for Web service parameters with the names Database server name, Database name, Server user account name, and Server user account password, which match the names of the input reader.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you do not need to explicitly pass the values for these parameters via webServiceParameters in the activity JSON below.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you do not need to explicitly pass the values for these parameters via webServiceParameters in the activity JSON below.

trans-unit.source: The parameters for writer (the ones with '1' suffix) are not automatically filled in by the Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: The parameters for writer (the ones with '1' suffix) are not automatically filled in by the Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you need to specify values for these parameters in the webServiceParameters section of the activity JSON.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you need to specify values for these parameters in the webServiceParameters section of the activity JSON.

trans-unit.source: Customer ID, scored labels, and scored probabilities are saved as comma separated columns.
trans-unit.target: Customer ID, scored labels, and scored probabilities are saved as comma separated columns.

trans-unit.source: The Data table name in this example corresponds to a table in the output database.
trans-unit.target: The Data table name in this example corresponds to a table in the output database.

trans-unit.source: Both start and end datetimes must be in ISO format.
trans-unit.target: Both start and end datetimes must be in ISO format.

trans-unit.source: The end time is optional.
trans-unit.target: The end time is optional.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".

trans-unit.source: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9999-09-09 as the value for the end property.
trans-unit.target: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9999-09-09 as the value for the end property.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title> for details about JSON properties.
